message_1:
Suppose you have a knapsack with a capacity of 15 pounds, and you are given a set of items with their respective weights and values:

Item 1: weight = 5 lbs, value = $10
Item 2: weight = 7 lbs, value = $14
Item 3: weight = 3 lbs, value = $7
Item 4: weight = 6 lbs, value = $12

Assuming you can only fit 10 pounds worth of items in your knapsack, what is the maximum value of items you can take with you? (You can take a partial item if needed.)
message_2:
To maximize the value of items in the knapsack, we should calculate the value-to-weight ratio for each item:

Item 1: value-to-weight ratio = $10 / 5 lbs = $2/lb
Item 2: value-to-weight ratio = $14 / 7 lbs = $2/lb
Item 3: value-to-weight ratio = $7 / 3 lbs = $2.33/lb
Item 4: value-to-weight ratio = $12 / 6 lbs = $2/lb

We should prioritize items with a higher value-to-weight ratio. In this case, Item 3 has the highest ratio. Since we can only fit 10 pounds worth of items, we should first take Item 3 (3 lbs, $7).

Now we have 7 pounds of capacity left in the knapsack. All remaining items have the same value-to-weight ratio ($2/lb). We can take Item 1 (5 lbs, $10) and still have 2 pounds of capacity left.

Since we can take a partial item, we can take 2/5 of Item 4 (2 lbs, $4) to fill the remaining capacity.

The maximum value of items we can take is $7 (Item 3) + $10 (Item 1) + $4 (partial Item 4) = $21.
